title: Saïd Maanan
text: Welcome to Saïd Maanan’s corner! I am a passionate reseacher and educator and currently serve as a Lecturer in Biostatistics and Epidemiology at the Higher Institute of Nursing Professions and Health Techniques in Al Hoceïma, Morocco.

title: Saïd Maanan
text: Welcome to Saïd Maanan’s corner! I am a passionate reseacher and educator and currently serve as a Lecturer in Biostatistics and Epidemiology at the Higher Institute of Nursing Professions and Health Techniques in Al Hoceïma, Morocco.

title: Saïd Maanan
text:
Education
I successfully earned my Ph.D. in Statistics from the University of Auckland on June 10, 2019. My doctoral research concentrated on innovating effective algorithms for estimating directed and undirected graphs in multivariate time series. Additionally, I introduced a novel information-theoretic criterion specifically tailored for optimal performance with time series data. Before pursuing my Ph.D., I achieved distinction in both a Master’s degree in Statistics and a Bachelor’s degree in Economics.

title: Saïd Maanan
text:
Experience
After completing my Ph.D., I held various research and teaching positions. As a postdoctoral researcher at Aalto University’s Department of Computer Science, I developed a profound understanding of the intersections between statistics and computer science. Additionally, my role as an adjunct lecturer in probability at Mohammed V University in Rabat enhanced my pedagogical skills through teaching a diverse group of students.
Currently, I am a lecturer in biostatistics at the Higher Institute of Nursing and Health Technology in Al Hoceïma, Morocco. This position has strengthened my practical applications of statistical methods in health care and medicine, sparking my passion for the field.

title: Teaching
text: Below are the courses I am currently teaching:

title: Teaching
text:
Biostatistics (Fall Semester)
This course provides a comprehensive introduction to statistical methodologies essential for research in health and life sciences. Students gain a strong foundation in both descriptive and inferential statistics, including techniques for data collection, sampling, estimation, and hypothesis testing. The course covers essential topics such as measures of central tendency and dispersion, correlation, contingency tables, and statistical indices. Practical sessions emphasize hands-on data analysis using statistical software such as SPSS and R, enabling students to apply statistical tools effectively in their final research projects. A significant focus is placed on developing critical thinking skills for interpreting results and making data-driven decisions in the health sector.
Below is an outline of the topics, content, and assignments for the course. Note that this schedule will be updated as the semester progresses, with all changes documented here.

title: Teaching
text:
Health Statistics (Spring Semester)
This course introduces students to the fundamental concepts of epidemiology and health statistics, with a focus on data-driven public health decision-making. Key topics include descriptive and analytical epidemiology, disease surveillance, and health data collection methods. Students learn to calculate and interpret critical epidemiological and statistical indicators such as incidence, prevalence, and mortality rates. The course also covers essential statistical methods for analyzing health data, including measures of central tendency and statistical indices. Through practical case studies and guided projects, students gain experience in conducting health surveys, analyzing data, and presenting findings. Software training, including the use of Epi Info, is incorporated to ensure students develop essential technical competencies.
Below is an outline of the topics, content, and assignments for the semester. Note that this schedule will be updated as the semester progresses, with all changes documented here.

title: Publications
text: Welcome to my publications page.

title: SEA2025 Conference
text:
JEF2025 and SEA2025
I am thrilled to announce that the 12th Days of Econometrics for Finance (JEF2025) will be held jointly with the 19th World Conference of the Spatial Econometrics Association (SEA2025) and the Spatial Econometrics Advanced Institute (SEAI).

Dates: May 2nd-8th, 2025

Location: Rabat, Morocco

This collaborative event brings together academics, practitioners, and policymakers to discuss cutting-edge research in:

Financial and spatial econometrics

Applied economics

Big Data analytics

Highlights:

Celebrate the 51st anniversary of the introduction of “Spatial Econometrics” by Jean Paelinck.

Attend talks and workshops led by experts.

Network with leading researchers and industry professionals from around the globe.

For more information, download the conference pamphlet (PDF).
Join us in Rabat to be part of this enriching experience!




 Back to top

title: Nursing Student Performance
text:
In this blog we will check the performance of students in one of Morocco’s nursing institutes to see if a pattern exists.


Code
data.Ex10.1 <- read.table("http://waveland.com/Glover-Mitchell/Example10-1.txt", header = TRUE)
tail(data.Ex10.1, n=3)


  Temperature HrtRt
7          14    32
8          16    29
9          18    32




Code
plot(data.Ex10.1$Temperature, data.Ex10.1$HrtRt,
     main = "Heart Rate vs Temperature",
     xlab = "Temperature (C)",
     ylab = "BPM")











Code
lm.Ex10.1 <- lm(HrtRt ~ Temperature, data = data.Ex10.1)
lm.Ex10.1



Call:
lm(formula = HrtRt ~ Temperature, data = data.Ex10.1)

Coefficients:
(Intercept)  Temperature  
      2.139        1.775  




Code
plot(data.Ex10.1, main="Heart Rate vs Temperature",
     xlab="Temperature (C)", ylab="BPM")
abline(lm.Ex10.1, col = "red")











Code
aov.Ex10.1 <- aov(HrtRt ~ Temperature, data = data.Ex10.1)
summary(aov.Ex10.1)


            Df Sum Sq Mean Sq F value   Pr(>F)    
Temperature  1  756.2   756.2   108.6 1.63e-05 ***
Residuals    7   48.7     7.0                     
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1




Code

                2.5 %   97.5 %
(Intercept) -2.394015 6.671792
Temperature  1.372241 2.177759




Code

                0.5 %   99.5 %
(Intercept) -4.569501 8.847278
Temperature  1.178944 2.371056




Code
new <- data.frame(Temperature = 9)
new


  Temperature
1           9




Code
predict(lm.Ex10.1, new, interval = "confidence")


       fit      lwr      upr
1 18.11389 15.99541 20.23237

new

title: New Plots for My Course
text:
Code
set.seed(123)
# Create sample data
n <- 100
x <- seq(1, n)
y_no_relation <- rnorm(n)
y_negative_nonlinear <- -log(x) + rnorm(n, sd = 0.25)
y_u_shaped <- -(x - 50)^2 + 2500 + rnorm(n, sd = 50)
y_s_shaped <- 1 / (1 + exp(-(x - 50) / 10)) * 100 + rnorm(n, sd = 5)
y_negative_linear <- -2 * x + rnorm(n, sd = 20)
y_positive_linear <- 2 * x + rnorm(n, sd = 20)

# Create true U-shaped curve
y_u_shaped <- 0.1 * x^2 - 10 * x + 400 + rnorm(n, sd = 50)

# Create plots
par(mfrow = c(2, 3), mar = c(4, 4, 2, 1))

plot(x, y_no_relation, main = "No Relation", type = "p", bg = "blue", pch = 21, col = "black", ylab = "y")
plot(x, y_negative_nonlinear, main = "Negative Non-linear", type = "p", bg = "green", pch = 21, col = "black", ylab = "y")
plot(x, y_u_shaped, main = "U-shaped", type = "p", bg = "red", pch = 21, col = "black", ylab = "y")
plot(x, y_s_shaped, main = "S-shaped", type = "p", bg = "purple", pch = 21, col = "black", ylab = "y")
plot(x, y_negative_linear, main = "Negative Linear", type = "p", bg = "orange", pch = 21, col = "black", ylab = "y")
plot(x, y_positive_linear, main = "Positive Linear", type = "p", bg = "brown", pch = 21, col = "black", ylab = "y")











Code
# Create sample data
n <- 100
x <- rnorm(n)
y <- 2 * x + rnorm(n)

# Calculate mean of y
mean_y <- mean(y)

# Create scatterplot
plot(x, y, main = "",
     xlab = "X", ylab = "Y", pch = 16, col = "blue")

# Add horizontal line for the mean of y
abline(h = mean_y, col = "red", lty = 2)

# Add vertical lines for each observation
for (i in 1:n) {
  if (y[i] > mean_y) {
    lines(c(x[i], x[i]), c(y[i], mean_y), col = "blue", lty = 2)
  } else {
    lines(c(x[i], x[i]), c(y[i], mean_y), col = "orange", lty = 2)
  }
}











Code
# Fit a linear regression model
fit <- lm(y ~ x)

# Create scatterplot
plot(x, y, main = "",
     xlab = "X", ylab = "Y", pch = 16, col = "blue")

# Add best fit line
abline(fit, col = "red", lty = 2)

# Add vertical lines for each observation
for (i in 1:n) {
  if (y[i] > predict(fit, data.frame(x = x[i]))) {
    lines(c(x[i], x[i]), c(y[i], predict(fit, data.frame(x = x[i]))), col = "blue", lty = 2)
  } else {
    lines(c(x[i], x[i]), c(y[i], predict(fit, data.frame(x = x[i]))), col = "orange", lty = 2)
  }
}

title: Hello World!
text:
Welcome and thank you for taking the time to check my first blog post on this website. This page serves as draft only, I want to see what code and figures would look like in case I generate them from inside Quarto.

A Box Plot


Code
boxplot(len ~ dose, data = ToothGrowth, frame = FALSE,
        border = c("#999999", "#E69F00", "#56B4E9"))











A Line Plot


Code
x <- 1:10
y1 <- x*x
y2  <- 2*y1

# Create a first line
plot(x, y1, type = "b", frame = FALSE, pch = 19, 
     col = "red", xlab = "x", ylab = "y")
# Add a second line
lines(x, y2, pch = 18, col = "blue", type = "b", lty = 2)
# Add a legend to the plot
legend("topleft", legend=c("Line 1", "Line 2"),
       col=c("red", "blue"), lty = 1:2, cex=0.8)

title: Research
text:
Vector Autoregressive Model
The analysis of multivariate time series is crucial for modeling and forecasting interconnected time-dependent data. One of the most commonly used models in this field is the Vector Autoregressive (VAR) Model. The VAR model of order \(p\) is defined as:
\[
\mathbf{Y}_t = \mathbf{A}_1 \mathbf{Y}_{t-1} + \mathbf{A}_2 \mathbf{Y}_{t-2} + \cdots + \mathbf{A}_p \mathbf{Y}_{t-p} + \mathbf{u}_t
\]
where:

\(\mathbf{Y}_t\) is a \(k \times 1\) vector of time series variables.
\(\mathbf{A}_i\) are \(k \times k\) coefficient matrices.
\(\mathbf{u}_t\) is a white noise vector with zero mean and covariance matrix \(\Sigma\).

My research focuses on enhancing the accuracy of conditional independence graph estimation for multivariate time series data. This involves developing robust methodologies to capture and visualize the dynamic interdependencies between multiple time series variables.

title: Research
text:
Quantile Regression
Quantile regression provides a more comprehensive analysis of the relationship between variables than mean regression by modeling conditional quantiles.
The LAD regression estimates the median of the dependent variable by minimizing the sum of absolute residuals. Given data points \((x_i, y_i)\) for \(i = 1, \dots, n\), the LAD estimator solves:
\[
\hat{\beta}_{\text{LAD}} = \arg\min_{\beta} \sum_{i=1}^n |y_i - x_i \beta|
\]
I investigate the asymptotic properties of the Least Absolute Deviation (LAD) estimator for linear models with polynomial regressors. My work aims to provide theoretical insights and practical improvements for modeling data with heterogeneous conditional quantiles and outliers.

title: Research
text:
Spatial Autoregressive Model
Spatial statistics deals with modeling spatially correlated data. One common model is the Spatial Autoregressive Model (SAR).
The SAR model is given by:
\[
\mathbf{y} = \rho \mathbf{W} \mathbf{y} + \mathbf{X} \boldsymbol{\beta} + \boldsymbol{\varepsilon}
\]
where:

\(\mathbf{y}\) is the dependent variable,
\(\mathbf{W}\) is a spatial weights matrix,
\(\rho\) is the spatial autoregressive parameter,
\(\mathbf{X}\) contains explanatory variables,
\(\boldsymbol{\varepsilon}\) is the error term.

My research aims to improve the performance of information-theoretic criteria, such as AIC and BIC, in estimating spatial autoregressive models. I explore these improvements under various conditions to ensure accurate model selection and parameter estimation in spatial data analysis.
